subject: Medicine
title: Gene Editing Ethics
description: A quick, practical guide to Gene Editing Ethics.

hook.text: In 2018, a scientist edited the genes of twin babies before birth. The world condemned it as reckless.

buildup.text: CRISPR gene editing can fix disease-causing mutations‚Äîbut also alter traits like intelligence or appearance.

discovery.text: Editing somatic cells treats one patient. Editing embryos changes every future generation permanently.

twist.text: Germline editing could eliminate genetic diseases forever‚Äîbut mistakes would be inherited by all descendants.

climax.text: The power to rewrite human DNA demands global consensus on where to draw the line.

punchline.text: Editing genes is easy. Editing ethics is hard.

quiz.question: Why is editing embryo genes more controversial than editing adult cells?
options: Changes to embryos are inherited by all future generations
Adult cells cannot be edited with current technology
Embryo editing only works on non-human species
